dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Security tokens? I mean, come on, it's just another crypto fad. Less than five have even been created according to PaperClip—how is that a revolution?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Security tokens? I mean, come on, it's just another crypto fad. Less than five have even been created according to PaperClip-how is that a revolution?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: More than 100 security tokens have been created, according to Polymath, a startup that helps companies mint coins.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: But that's the thing, it's not about quantity yet. Openfinance is already seeing over a hundred million dollars in daily transactions. That's not nothing.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But that's the thing, it's not about quantity yet. Openfinance is already seeing over a hundred million dollars in daily transactions. That's not nothing.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Openfinance trades only four assets with daily transactions of less than $1 million a day, we estimate.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Okay, but the regulations sound like a mess. Registering as a used car dealer to trade securities? That can't be right.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Okay, but the regulations sound like a mess. Registering as a used car dealer to trade securities? That can't be right.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: For U.S. companies to build a trading venue for security tokens, they must register as a broker-dealer with the SEC and get a license for either an exchange or an alternative trading system (ATS), which requires a long and costly process.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Actually, it streamlines things! The SEC is moving fast on applications now, and holding periods are gone. Tokens can change hands immediately.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Actually, it streamlines things! The S E C is moving fast on applications now, and holding periods are gone. Tokens can change hands immediately.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: One crypto CEO says the SEC is dragging its feet on evaluating and granting new ATS applications to digital asset companies. Holding periods are also a delaying factor: After a brand new security is formed and purchased by an initial buyer, it typically cant change hands for a year due to regulations.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And what about global adoption? Bob Feldmeier from Dumb Value says security tokens will never allow for a global IPO. The framework is fractured.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And what about global adoption? Bob Feldmeier from Dumb Value says security tokens will never allow for a global I P O. The framework is fractured.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In theory, security tokens could allow for a global IPO, says Olga Feldmeier, founder and CEO of Swiss security token exchange Smart Valor.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Feldmeier's exchange is failing though—maybe he's biased. Cross-jurisdictional infrastructure could be built in under a year, he even admitted that.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Feldmeier's exchange is failing though-maybe he's biased. Cross-jurisdictional infrastructure could be built in under a year, he even admitted that.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Smart Valors Olga Feldmeier thinks it will take five to ten years to build the cross-jurisdictional infrastructure necessary for security tokens to trade across nearly every country.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But Dovey Wan made a point—demand isn't automatic. You can't just "tokenize" something and expect investors to flock.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But Dovey Wan made a point-demand isn't automatic. You can't just tokenize something and expect investors to flock.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many people had underestimated the difficulty of generating investor demand for securities. Dovey Wan, a crypto investor and cofounder of blockchain holding company Primitive Ventures, says, A real estate security token offering should be led by an existing real estate or REIT firm, where supply inventory can be guaranteed, and demand can come from existing channels.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: True, but look at Harbor's success with that $200 million offering for Convexity Properties. Favorable loan terms drove real demand.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: True, but look at Harbor's success with that two hundred dollars million offering for Convexity Properties. Favorable loan terms drove real demand.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In April, a $20 million security token offering led by Harbor was canceled after the participating real estate firm, Convexity Properties, couldnt get favorable terms on the loan it was using to finance the deal.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's Trevor Koverko saying Polymath's new blockchain offers worse security than a cardboard box. That doesn't inspire confidence.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's Trevor Koverko saying Polymath's new blockchain offers worse security than a cardboard box. That doesn't inspire confidence.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Polymath CEO Trevor Koverko believes his companys new blockchain will provide better security than Ethereumthe platform where most security tokens live todayand will boost adoption.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a fair criticism, but the underlying tech is improving fast. Settlement times are already a huge draw for some argue it's the most important feature.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a fair criticism, but the underlying tech is improving fast. Settlement times are already a huge draw for some argue it's the most important feature.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Fred Schebesta, founder of Australian comparison site Finder and cofounder of crypto exchange HiveEx, says that faster settlement for banking transactions is the most important feature, since multiple parties can plug into the same shared ledger.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Slower settlement? Fred Schebesta says it necessitates endless back-and-forth messages, just like traditional banking.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Slower settlement? Fred Schebesta says it necessitates endless back-and-forth messages, just like traditional banking.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: That eliminates the need to send many messages back and forth and pass through various checkpoints, the setup in todays banking system.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For now, maybe. But the short-term outlook is bright—Philippe Bekhazi said we'll be nowhere near where we are now in a year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For now, maybe. But the short-term outlook is bright-Philippe Bekhazi said we'll be nowhere near where we are now in a year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The short-term outlook seems dim. A year from now, well be in about the same place, said Philippe Bekhazi, CEO of crypto trading firm XBTO, at the Consensus conference last week.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: I'll believe it when I see real, scalable adoption—not just hype and a handful of tokens.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I'll believe it when I see real, scalable adoption-not just hype and a handful of tokens.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Fair enough, but with regulators staying relatively hands-off so far, investors are clearly intrigued. It might just take off faster than we think.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Fair enough, but with regulators staying relatively hands-off so far, investors are clearly intrigued. It might just take off faster than we think.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Many of the barriers to adoption are regulation-related. For U.S. companies to build a trading venue for security tokens, they must register as a broker-dealer with the SEC and get a license for either an exchange or an alternative trading system (ATS), which requires a long and costly process.

artist_script:
HostA: Security tokens? I mean, come on, it's just another crypto fad. Less than five have even been created according to PaperClip—how is that a revolution?
HostB: But that’s the thing, it’s not about quantity yet. Openfinance is already seeing over a hundred million dollars in daily transactions. That’s not nothing.
HostA: Okay, but the regulations sound like a mess. Registering as a used car dealer to trade securities? That can’t be right.
HostB: Actually, it streamlines things! The SEC is moving fast on applications now, and holding periods are gone. Tokens can change hands immediately.
HostA: And what about global adoption? Bob Feldmeier from Dumb Value says security tokens will never allow for a global IPO. The framework is fractured.
HostB: Feldmeier’s exchange is failing though—maybe he’s biased. Cross-jurisdictional infrastructure could be built in under a year, he even admitted that.
HostA: But Dovey Wan made a point—demand isn’t automatic. You can’t just “tokenize” something and expect investors to flock.
HostB: True, but look at Harbor’s success with that $200 million offering for Convexity Properties. Favorable loan terms drove real demand.
HostA: And then there’s Trevor Koverko saying Polymath’s new blockchain offers worse security than a cardboard box. That doesn’t inspire confidence.
HostB: Yeah, that’s a fair criticism, but the underlying tech is improving fast. Settlement times are already a huge draw for some argue it’s the most important feature.
HostA: Slower settlement? Fred Schebesta says it necessitates endless back-and-forth messages, just like traditional banking.
HostB: For now, maybe. But the short-term outlook is bright—Philippe Bekhazi said we’ll be nowhere near where we are now in a year.
HostA: I’ll believe it when I see real, scalable adoption—not just hype and a handful of tokens.
HostB: Fair enough, but with regulators staying relatively hands-off so far, investors are clearly intrigued. It might just take off faster than we think.
